Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Analyzing Complex Data with a Topological Lens

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the modern data-centric era, one is constantly faced with the task of extracting intelligent summaries out of diverse, complex data. This task is becoming increasingly challenging as the data becomes more complex. Recent work has demonstrated that topological ideas and concepts can be powerful in extracting essential structures/features that are hidden in data. Although existing topological methods are promising and powerful, they are limited when analyzing data that is laced with complex maps (e.g, non-real valued functions) and temporal components.

This project aims to broaden the scope of topological techniques and methodologies for analyzing such complex data. Specifically, the PIs will investigate novel methodologies and computational issues to address key challenges caused by complexity in modern data: the diverse properties/information associated with data, the dynamic/time-varying behavior of data, and the sheer volume of the data. The project will provide a theoretical understanding of a recently proposed framework, called Mapper, and its extension to a multiscale formulation. It will explore the use of persistence methodologies, including zigzag constructions, for understanding the time-varying aspects of data.

The geometric and topological ideas behind this project will bring new perspectives to the important field of computational data analysis. A successful algorithmic theory for summarizing and characterizing complex and dynamic data with topological techniques can provide a powerful tool for data exploration and analysis in various fields of science and engineering. The educational impact of this project is in a large synergy between mathematics and computer science motivated by real applications. The findings from the project are planned to be part of the course materials that the PIs develop. This project will train graduate students who will develop skills in mathematics and theoretical computer science, most notably in algorithms and topology, in writing efficient software, and its application to analyzing data sets. The combination of such skills is becoming increasingly essential in modern data science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the modern data-centric era, we are constantly faced with the task of extracting intelligent summaries out of diverse, complex data. This task is becoming increasingly challenging as the data becomes more complex. This project developed efficient and effective topological methods to characterize and summarize such complex data, to help address this challenge in modern data analysis. Specifically, this project focused mainly on three aspects: (i) complexity stemming from diverse properties / information associated with data, (ii) complexity caused by the dynamic / time-varying behavior of data, and (iii) complexity arising due to sheer volume of the data. The project advanced not only the theoretical and algorithmic foundation behind these problems, but also led to new practical data analysis algorithms and methodologies. It helped build algorithmic foundations for modern data science.

More specifically, to model and characterize complex information associated to data, the PIs have developed a novel (topological) multiscale mapper framework as a way to summarize complex maps (modeling different types of information associated with input data). The project further provided theoretical characterization of the information encoded in such multiscale summaries. This project also developed theoretical understanding of a commonly used topological persistence-based feature summary for complex graph data, as well as efficient algorithms to compute loop features.

To help address the massive size of modern data, the project developed an efficient software, SimBa, to compute topological summary for complex data. The PIs also develop effective strategies for data sparsification and denoising. 

To address dynamic nature of data, the PIs developed novel ways to summarize time-dependent data via topological objects, as well as efficient algorithms for maintaining cluster structure for time-varying data.

The investigate leads several papers published in top venues for algorithms, and for computational geometry / applied topology, such as SoDA (SIAM/ACM Sympos. Discrete Algs.), SoCG (Sympos. Comput. Geom.) and the Journal for Applied and Computational Topology. In addition to the publications, various presentations and talks about these results, three software packages were developed and made publicly available.

On the educational front, this project fostered synergy between mathematics and computational science motivated by real applications. The project provided research training and education for a diverse group of graduate students, and helped them develop skills in both mathematical analysis, algorithms design, and applications. Results from this project have been assimilated into material for courses on topological data analysis.
